title: Douglass and anonymous on freedom songs - language

content.description:
Source 1
“[When I was a slave] I did not fully understand the deep meanings of those rude, and apparently incoherent songs. They were...loud, long and deep, breathing the prayer and complaint of souls boiling over with the bitterest anguish. Every tone was a testimony against slavery.... To those songs I trace my first understanding of the dehumanizing character of slavery. Those songs still follow me, to deepen my hatred of slavery and [strengthen] my sympathies for my brethren in bonds.”
Source: Frederick Douglass, My Bondage and My Freedom, autobiography, 1855 

Source 2
Didn’t my Lord deliver Daniel,
deliver Daniel, deliver Daniel,
Didn’t my Lord deliver Daniel,
An’ why not-a every man?

He delivered Daniel from the lion’s den,Daniel, Jonah, and the “Hebrew children” are from the Old Testament; they were saved from certain death by God because of the strength of their belief.
Jonah from the belly of the whale,Daniel, Jonah, and the “Hebrew children” are from the Old Testament; they were saved from certain death by God because of the strength of their belief.
and the Hebrew children from the fiery furnace,Daniel, Jonah, and the “Hebrew children” are from the Old Testament; they were saved from certain death by God because of the strength of their belief.
And why not every man?
Source: Anonymous author, “Didn’t My Lord Deliver Daniel,” spiritual, nineteenth century
content.question: Which of the following best explains the significance of the language used in Source 2?

choices.label: It drew inspiration from both white American and Indigenous American religious traditions.
It connected biblical themes with the daily experiences of enslaved African Americans.
It preserved folktales that unified African Americans in times of adversity.
It reflected the hopes of free African Americans for achieving greater economic opportunities.

content.answer: It connected biblical themes with the daily experiences of enslaved African Americans.
